thread.title: Boynton Beach set for district clash vs. Boyd Anderson
thread.title_full: Boynton Beach set for district clash vs. Boyd Anderson

author: Patrick Maks
title: Boynton Beach set for district clash vs. Boyd Anderson
text:
Boynton Beach set for district clash vs. Boyd Anderson Game of the Week Preview: Boyd Anderson vs. Boynton Beach 
The Cobras battle the Tigers Friday night in Boynton Beach. 
The Cobras battle the Tigers Friday night in Boynton Beach. Patrick Maks South Florida Sun-Sentinel Game of the Week: Boynton Beach, Boyd Anderson clash in 6A duel 
BOYNTON BEACH — During a recent practice at Boynton Beach, first-year coach Errik Lowe stood near midfield wearing a pair of dark sunglasses and a camouflage safari hat. With his whistle in hand, it's clear there is a new sheriff here, and this stadium is his town. 
"You know the old cliches? The hard-work-always-pays-off stuff?" Lowe said. "(We're) not just saying it, but doing it." 
Lowe, who was hired in March after a lengthy tenure at Lake Worth, wants to usher in a new era for a team that was in disrepair. 
"I take over the program, and a lot of kids were used to missing practice, missing weight-lifting sessions, missing team functions and not necessarily having a valid excuse," he said. "And in my opinion, as far as the standards that we have, there are no excuses. You're there." 
So far, Lowe's approach has lifted the Tigers to a surprisingly successful season despite returning only three starters from last year's team, which finished 9-2 and advanced to the Class 6A quarterfinals. Dave Brousseau breaks down Broward and Palm County high school football 
South Florida Sports with Perk: Chris Perkins sits down with Dave Brousseau to talk high school football and top games of the week. 
South Florida Sports with Perk: Chris Perkins sits down with Dave Brousseau to talk high school football and top games of the week. See more videos 
But on Friday night, Boynton Beach (4-2, 1-0) faces a litmus test of sorts when it hosts Boyd Anderson (6-1, 1-0) in a pivotal District 15-6A clash with the postseason looming. 
Lowe said neither he nor his players are shying away from the spotlight as they aim for another playoff berth. "I don't downplay anything. We're in that moment," he said. "We have that opportunity when a lot of people didn't think we'd be anywhere close to it." 
Lowe and his coaching staff inherited a shell of a team; the Tigers lost 32 seniors to graduation, including former star quarterback Lamar Jackson, who is now the starter at Louisville. 
Dave Brousseau ranks the county's deep well of signal-callers from this season. 
"We knew going in it was going to be — I wouldn't say a rough season — but a challenging season," Lowe said. 
Indeed, Boynton Beach has had its shares of highs and lows this year. The Tigers were routed 48-6 at Dwyer in their season opener and lost 14-13 at Lake Worth two weeks later. But since, they've won three straight and find themselves in a position to keep hopes of a playoff berth afloat. "When you're losing 32 seniors," Lowe said, "no one would ever think you'd be 4-2." 
Boyd Anderson, though, is no pushover. The Cobras average 28 points and are led by one of the area's best quarterbacks in junior Shabazz Telfort, who is expected to return after missing the last two weeks with a knee injury. 
"The kids understand — and we've stressed it every day this week — Boyd Anderson is going to bring their A-game. And we have to bring ours," Lowe said. "Some guys are going to have to make some plays for us." 
In particular, the Tigers will look to junior QB Curtis Williams to keep the Cobras off balance. 
"This game is going to be important for him," Lowe said. "He knows that and he's working this week and concentrated on what he's supposed to do." 
Despite playing at home, Boynton Beach — with its youthful, inexperienced roster — likely enters Friday's game as the underdog. That's how Lowe likes it. 
"I accept the challenge," he said, "and we embrace it."
